sn12.40:1.4: This evocative passage is also at Ud 8.4:3.4, MN 144:11.6, and SN 35.87:11.6. | “Inclination” is nati, from a root meaning “to bend”. Sometimes used in the sense of a “inclination of mind” (MN 19:6.1), here, as the following lines make clear, it refers to the mind inclining to rebirth; explained by the commentary as “craving”. Compare the English idiom, “one is bent on destruction”.
sn12.40:1.5: The phrase “coming and going” is often used in the context of rebirth (eg. AN 5.57:11.2).
